ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about Chinese history that helped me contextualize the current US and China relations. The framework of the course brilliantly leads you through many perspectives and makes you critically evaluate the integral differences and similarities between Eastern and Western cultures. There is not an overload of readings, but the ones that are assigned are genuinely so interesting it does not feel like homework.
Knowledge and skills in many different aspects of China
Writing skills and how to structure arguments better in short essays.

Chinese history, tradition, and how they led into the formation of modern China. Central topics to China including science and technology, cultural revolution, and the narrative of China "catching up" with the West.
n/a
Fantastic course! It's given me a solid overview on the history, current events, and culture of China that help me understand some global discussions I see in the news much more deeply.
Interesting course, good content
China in different perspectives
I developed a profound knowledge of the history and modern role of China.
Great course
New insights into China's culture, history, and government over the centuries.
Gained knowledge on Chinese history, geopolitical relations, what Chinese literature looks like
I learned about Chinas perception of the west and the history behind them

This course allowed me to gain insight into modern China from a six different themes from a historical context. Additionally, I learned how to critically analyze texts and formulate arguments on different topics about China.
I learned a bit of general information about Chinese history/current events, but I don't think the course was super well-organized and I didn't gain as much insight as I think I could have.
learned a lot about Chinese history and learned about it's position to the Western world and why current politics are the way they are
This class provided a lot of insight on the workings and politics of China throughout history and in the modern world.
some deeper insight into recent headlines about China; historical context for cultural understanding
I developed an understanding of Chinese history and culture as well as the history and current state of U.S.-China relations.

I learned about some of the broader themes surrounding US and China. We learned about the history of the Chinese language, science and development, and four other keys (aka themes). We also looked at more contemporary developments, like the tensions between Taiwan and China through semiconductors, the AI tech race, the power of political art with Ai Wei Wei, the importance of the Arctic in international development, etc.

I really enjoyed this class - I learnt a lot about China from a non-US lens, I think this was very important in really understanding China and seeing how misunderstandings and cultural clashes can rise

I loved all the readings - especially, all the novels and sci-fi!

I gained insight on China as a whole, uninfluenced by American propaganda. I liked the six keys because of the different perspectives you could view China in. Overall, the course was well thought-out and influential to me.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings are a strength of the course. The response papers make you think critically about them in an exciting way. The lectures however could sometimes be dull. They were always filled with interesting information, but some times did not connect to that weeks reading or response paper prompt.
Very engaging lectures and discussion sections
Material was highly engaging and small group discussion sessions were very enjoyable.

Strength and weakness: covers a great breadth of information. Each of the six keys were pretty much unrelated to each other. However, each is important to know on its own and is of great interest to dive deeper into.
n/a
lectures were unrelated to the content we were being graded on.

This course was open to the public, which was interesting, but meant that our readings often weren't connected to the lecture, I wish there was more connection. Professor Tsu is an amazing lecturer and our discussion sections with TFs were always very productive.
Interesting, maybe less focus on technical details but overall good balance between broad and narrow

interesting course
grading unclear
n.a

Strengths - Discussion was great
Weaknesses - Lectures disorganized
Lectures too much like a long rant, Prof has really great knowledge of very interesting and uncommon subjects, but felt like the actual lectures catered to the New Haveners that took it
It was not as engaging as I had hoped for

The strength of the class was the lectures were well organized into the different thematic focuses of the class, and the discussions were very insightful, productive, and well-led. The weakness of this course was there were very few lecture slides to follow along with for the class and the expectation for writing assignments were sometimes a little vague.
I think that the sections were fairly well-organized but the lectures were all over the place and it was really hard to follow the thread sometimes.

strengths = super interesting and covered a lot of material
weaknesses = disorganized and the topics covered in lecture did not relate/clearly align to section work and assigned reading
The assignments were rather unrelated to lectures.

strengths - exploring interesting topics, gaining further insight into current events regarding China and learning about historical context
weaknesses - course could be better organized; structure of content in lectures and course at large could be hard to follow, especially for those without prior experience in East Asian studies

The lecture format is in a podcast format, which is fascinating to listen to, but it is definitely on a rather unorganized side, and it is hard to follow sometimes. If you have no background in Chinese history, it is very tough to follow in the first half o the class.

I really liked the format of the course. I enjoyed that there were six different topics that we focused on throughout the course, allowing us to learn about a breadth of different areas. The lecture format accompanied by discussion sections was engaging.

It was a good survey course for understanding China with some historical perspective. The fact that the course covered several units and fields from history to politics, to literature, to technology, made it difficult to re-adjust and apply feedback from previous assignments.

Strengths: section and the guest speakers really helped the course. The section afforded us the opportunity to really dig deeper into the humanistic side of US-China relations, while the guest speakers offered a contemporary view with some of the world's leaders in the field (I particularly loved the last unit with the technological speakers and reporters!)

Weaknesses: the lectures were extremely unengaging. I know this was partially due to technical difficulties, but not only were lectures not recorded as the course staff said they would be, but even attending them live wasn't helpful. Professor Tsu's slides only had like a handful of pictures, and the rest was a monologue of analysis. Providing more interactive activities or more dynamic presentations would have made this class much better -- I didn't get much out of the lectures at all outside of section and the readings. 

The readings also were rather uneven. Assigning 300-400 page books at the end of the semester was a difficult way to engage with the material. It would have been helpful to assign a more reasonable, 80-100 page reading load each week, instead of just dumping it on students.
I enjoyed all the guest speakers - wish there was more question time at the end

Overall, I did not find the readings and lecture to be very related. The assignments could be done without attending lecture. Discussion Section was a great place to discuss the different concepts, which I loved to do.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to any student at Yale. Not an overwhelming workload at all. Grading is straightforward and clear feedback is given. The course covers so many different aspects of Chinese society that there is bound to be a few weeks where a student is interested. Plus, very relevant to current geopolitics.
Yes, if you are interested in international relations, East Asian Studies, etc.
Yes the material was very engaging and the assignments were fun to complete.
Yes, if they are interested in or affected by modern China, its culture, past, and/or tradition.
n/a
I would absolutely recommend! I had a fantastic time learning in this course, and it is very accessible.
Yes, good content good TA enjoyed it
yes
yes i would
Yes, but only if they no virtually nothing about China.
No, take another class on china
If you are really interested in China then yes
I would recommend this class if you looking to get an introduction in understanding modern China from different perspectives, and the lectures were very interesting.

Although I was really excited to take this class, I wouldn't really recommend it to other students because the lack of coherence of the lectures made it hard to gain meaningful insights on the course content.

for those looking to gain some insight into current events regarding China, yes, but would recommend taking another course if one is looking to get a solid grasp/foundation to dive further into East Asian studies

China in Six Keys (EALL 256)  part of the 2023 DeVane Lectures program  was a powerful, important and topical class taught by Yales Dr. Jing Tsu. For those not familiar, the DeVane Lectures program opens up Yale classrooms to non-Yale affiliated New Haven residents at no cost  and as a result, our class was often filled with as many adult and continuing education learners as there were Yale students. That said, the courses discussion sections are exclusively for credit-earning students. 

China in Six Keys ambitiously tackles six contemporary topics (ranging from Chinas ambitions in the Arctic to an examination of the artistic work and life journey of artist Ai Weiwei) about modern China and examines them all contemporaneously as well as in deeper historical context. Against the backdrop of those topics, Dr. Tsu focuses on how China has historically adapted, assimilated, rejected and integrated with a world system that has been largely shaped by the West. Each of the individual topics offer opportunities for students to think deeply about and engage with original source material. Dr. Tsu makes clear that her goal is to draw lessons from the past to help students better understand the drivers behind the choices China and the West will make in the present and future  what those choices might mean. The course easily achieves and surpasses her goal.

Class mechanics are straight-forward; weekly lectures and discussion sections. Grading is entirely based on class attendance, discussion section participation and six (relatively short, approximately 600-to-750-word essays  graded on a check/check plus basis) on each of the topics the course covers. While there are suggested prompts for each of the papers, they are by design open-ended and invite students to voice their own ideas, interpretations and connections with the material/subjects.   

While I really valued and enjoyed the lectures, I ***loved*** the smaller, more intimate discussion sections. I was incredibly fortunate to have Melodie Liu TF our section - and she was phenomenal. Melodie brought her deep domain expertise, backed by thoughtful and strong classroom moderator skills to each session - always facilitating meaningful discussions; always with a positive, encouraging approach. Beyond the actual sessions, the feedback she provided on each and every paper I submitted was reflective of the extraordinary time and care she invested reviewing our work. Her comments and questions about my essays were insightful and helpful. Reading her feedback on each assignment inspired me to think even more deeply about the themes and topics we were covering; and often motivated me to go back and spend more time with the original source material. 

Because it was part of the DeVane Lecture series, Im not sure if/when this course might be offered again. That said, if you have an interest in better understanding China, its role in the world as well as the historical drivers behind current economic, social and political trends within Modern China and how those might effect the global world order, China in Six Keys is a course you cant afford to miss.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! The topics we learned about were engaging and the class was designed to facilitate student learning.

Maybe. If you're looking for a gut and are interested in US-China relations, then this is a good course for you, especially if this is your first introduction to a humanities class. For more advanced majors or students in their humanities coursework, though, you won't get much out of this. You might get a gem in section though which salvages this class. I would see which guest speakers are going to come and if you're interested in them.
Yes - I think Yale and the USA more generally has a strong anti-China rhetoric and this class really allowed me to see China as China and not an Americanised version of China
Yes, absolutely. I felt like I learned a lot.
